title: Roger Federer Stunned at U.S. Open by Former Protégé
text:
“Baby Fed” has finally broken through.

Former tennis phenom Grigor Dimitrov stunned third-seeded Roger Federer in the U.S. Open quarterfinals Tuesday, 3-6, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2.

It’s a career result for the 28-year-old Bulgarian, whose elegant game drew early, flattering comparisons to the Swiss legend’s—comparisons that seemed to weigh on Dimitrov as he struggled to live up to such starry billing.

Unseeded in this tournament, Dimitrov entered the Open as the 78th ranked men’s singles player in the world. More pressingly, he’d never beaten Federer—his friend and sometimes practice partner—in seven prior matches.

But inside a packed Arthur Ashe Stadium—per usual, pulling heavily for Federer—Dimitrov played composed, consistent tennis, recovering from his mistakes and taking advantage of his opponent’s weary body.

Federer, 38, appeared to tire as the match dragged on. He took a lengthy medical break after losing the fourth set, but it did little good, as Dimitrov roared out to a 4-0 lead and closed out the match without trouble.

It was a disappointing exit for Federer, who played brilliantly to reach the Wimbledon final this year, but has not won the U.S. Open since 2008. His loss also quashed hopes of a Federer-Nadal final on Sunday; amazingly, the two rivals have never played each other at this tournament.

Grigor Dimitrov celebrates after defeating Roger Federer. Photo: john g mabanglo/Shutterstock

For years, Dimitrov has been hopefully portrayed as one of tennis’s next generation of champions, and his all-court game and one-handed backhand helped propel those heady comparisons to Federer.

The hype was not without merit: Dimitrov has been ranked as high as No. 3 in the world, and reached the semifinals of Wimbledon in 2014 and the Australian Open in 2017.

Still, to Dimitrov, that “Baby Fed” nickname seemed to be more of a tiresome albatross than a compliment. Dimitrov entered Tuesday’s match having lost seven of his last eight matches on tour, dropping his ranking out of the Top 50.

Now Dimitrov will face Russia’s Daniil Medvedev Friday with a chance to go to his first major tournament final.

The 23-year-old, fifth-seeded Medvedev won his quarterfinal against Stan Wawrinka earlier in the day, 7-6(6), 6-3, 1-6, 6-1. Like Dimitrov, he has yet to make the final of a major.

Write to Jason Gay at Jason.Gay@wsj.com
